list.text: Creator: Joshua B. Miller, Department of Economics, University of Melbourne, joshua.benjamin.miller@gmail.com, https://www.joshua-benjamin-miller.com/

This graph illustrates the income and substitution effects from a tax on good 2 for Cobb-Douglas /Perfect Complements/Perfect Substitutes utility.  The transfer that IE/SE is based on needs to be adjusted manually, but the utility compensating transfer (compensating variation) can be toggled on/off.
Budget line with interest rate change

list.title: 8. Optimal  with interest rate change **adjustable** transfer (with IC). Note: SE, IE are based on this, so need to adjust appropriately.

list.text: budget line with tax and transfer

list.title: 11. Optimal with interest rate increase with (utility) compensating variation (with IC)
12. SE (rotation on IC),IE (shift),TE (rotation on axis) with arrows

list.label: There is no substitution effect under perfect complements utility function,
The optimal bundle for the original the compensated budget line are all bundle A
Good x can't substitute Good y, vise versa.
consumer choose to buy the same good only before and after the price changes
the good is not substituted by the other-> no substitution effect.
consumer choose to buy the same good only before and after the price changes
the good is not substituted by the other-> no substitution effect.
consumer switch from only consume one good to only consume the other good
all the originally consumed goods are substituted by the other goods -> only SE

list.text: note: the Vector function creates a list of points (ordered pairs), which define the vertices of an arrow. To see an arrow and not points the Desmos settings need to be adjusted to have "points" off and "lines" on

list.title: Perfect complements (keep off all folders except 1.)
